description: eaves +‎ drop; the "listening" sense derives from the notion of the listener standing in the area denoted by the physical sense.

entries.meaning: The dripping of rain from the eaves of a house.
The space around a house on which such water drips.
(countable) A concealed aperture through which an occupant of a building can surreptitiously listen to people talking at an entrance to the building.
(countable) The act of intentionally hearing a conversation not intended to be heard.
examples: Were you having a little eavesdrop on us last night?

verbs.description: eavesdrop (third-person singular simple present eavesdrops, present participle eavesdropping, simple past and past participle eavesdropped)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To hear a conversation one is not intended to hear; to listen in.
examples: I hope nobody was eavesdropping on our conversation last night, since it got so personal.

entries.meaning: (zoology) To listen for another organism's calls, so as to exploit them.
examples: […]  Eastern Red Bat will eavesdrop on the sonar calls of other red bats to locate potential insect prey.
